On average they had negative financial and property wealth of £4,900 in 2018, up from £3,900 in 2014.The data also highlights a growing regional ide. Total wealth in London has jumped almost 80 per cent since 2008 while the east midlands and northeast are both more than 10 per cent down. London also has the largest ide between wealthy and poor citizens of any UK region.Robert Palmer, executive director of Tax Justice UK, said: “These figures reveal that wealth inequality has increased over the past decade and remains stubbornly high. This has real-world consequences. Access to wealth gives you more life opportunities and better health.”&nbsp“Inequality has been a major talking point in this election. Taxing wealth more has to be part of the solution if we are to get the public services voters consistently say they want.”The wealth boom has not been mirrored in wage growth, with average wages still slightly below a peak reached in 2008. Household debt, including loans and credit cards, is also rising, up 11 per cent to £119bn in the two years to March 2018.George Bangham, research analyst at the Resolution Foundation, said: “While incomes have stagnated over the past decade, our national wealth has continued to boom.“But the UK’s £14.6 trillion of wealth is highly concentrated and unequally spread. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.'Of course there is no victory, because the only thing we want to see is real action'Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg has urged politicians to listen to the voices of young people during the second week of international climate negotiations.The Swedish teenage activist was speaking today as thousands of youth activists gathered in central Madrid to voice their anger about the slow pace of progress so far. The protest, organised by the climate strike movement Fridays for Future, was also attended by many students, families and professionals.Just a few miles away, in the stuffy surroundings of Madrid’s largest conference centre, negotiators from across the world continued to try to hammer out the final details of the 2015 Paris Agreement.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesMs Thunberg made a surprise appearance at the conference on Friday to meet other young activists before being whisked away by security. She had hitch-hiked her way across the world after the talks were moved from Chile due to civil unrest.Ms Thunberg later told reporters that the voices of climate strikers were being heard but not enough “concrete action” was taking place. Of course there is no victory, because the only thing we want to see is real action,” she said. “So we have achieved a lot, but if you look at it from a certain point of view we have achieved nothing.Created with Sketch. to push for more ambitious outcomes in Madrid. Speaking at a panel run by the Association of Small Island States, Samoan student Brianna Fruean from 350 Samoa and the Pacific Climate Warriors, said it was critical to remember that some nations represented at the talks were fighting for sheer survival. “World leaders need to know that people like me are watching them.”The key sticking points of the talks, which began on Monday, are how to establish new international rules for carbon markets and how to help poorer countries pay for losses and damage caused by climate change.A decision on carbon market rules is proving tricky because of disagreements about what to do with the surplus credits from earlier emission trading schemes and how to avoid ‘double counting’ emission cuts that are traded overseas.Progress on loss and damage is also a long way off. Many vulnerable nations are pressing for a new financial mechanism to pay for major, one-off disasters such as hurricanes and typhoons, as well as longer term problems exacerbated by climate change.Hillary Clinton says male leaders are ‘scared’ of Greta ThunbergBut influential developed countries, particularly Australia, Japan and Switzerland (as well as the US, which is withdrawing from the Paris Agreement), do not want finance on the table at all because they think it will open the floodgates for future compensation claims.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Russia in particular is resistant to the discussion of human rights in any context.An underlying concern at the talks is the extent to which countries will be expected to be more ambitious when they revise their national carbon-cutting commitments next year.A recent report by UN Environment Programme warned that there was a huge gap between what countries had committed to so far and the goal of keeping global warming to a reasonably safe level. It found global fossil fuel production needs to be more than halved by 2030 to stay within a 1.5c temperature rise, with coal the biggest offender.Pressure to come to an agreement on these issues will rise next week as high-ranking national ministers arrive in Madrid. title: general election 2019 leaders debate boris
story: The Tory leader criticised Jeremy Corbyn, as he revealed his plans for leaving the EU.Follow our General Election  live blog below for all the latest news and updates...Yougov polling reveals what the public thought of the heated debate.The two leaders went up against each other in their final head-to-head tonight, but both failed to land a killer blow on the other. Here were some of the best moments from the hour-long BBC debate tonight. On Brexit:Mr Johnson : #How can you get a deal, a new deal from Brussels for Brexit,you dont actually believe in it  Thats the mystery that I fail to understand.#Mr Corbyn: #We will have a final say. I want to have a government that represents the whole country.#On the NHS:Mr Johnson: On the accusations that he wants to sell the NHS, Mr Johnson said: #This is pure Bermuda Triangle stuff. Weve heard it time and time again from the Labour Party during this election campaign.#Well be hearing about little green men next.#Mr Johnson added: #Under no circumstances will we sell it off to anybody in any kind of trade deal.#Mr Corbyn: #There is no plan to bring in a four-day week in the NHS. #Mr Johnson will spend at least seven years negotiating with the USA on access to our public services, on the price of medicines in Britain, on the access to our national health service and he knows he cant get a deal quickly with the USA because of the way in which the USA political system works, so what he will do is walk out of a relationship with the EU into a relationship with nobody.#On the economy:Mr Johnson: #Labour always ends their time in office with an economic crisis# Corbyn and McDonnell would start their time in office with an economic crisis.#Mr Corbyn: #Labour is ambitious for our country and ambitious for you.#On security and the union:Mr Johnson : #I do find it slightly curious to say the least to be lectured about the union between Great Britain and Northern Ireland by a man who all his political le has campaigned to break up that union and actually supported for four decades the IRA their in their campaign violently to destroy it.#It is extraordinary and wrong [the London Bridge terrorist] should be out on automatic early release.#Mr Corbyn: #There are no plans whatsoever to disband MI or any part of the security services# We need the security on our streets, it doesnt come on the cheap.On racism:Mr Johnson: #His unwillingness to take a stand, to stand up for Jewish people in the Labour Party# to put an arm around them, is in my view a failure of leadership. You cant be neutral on this issue.#Mr Corbyn: #A failure of leadership is where you use racist remarks to describe people in dferent countries or in our society.#We need a world where we treat people with respect.#Barry Gardiner claims John Trickett and Richard Burgon would back a new Brexit deal.That may be news to them.. has anyone asked John TrickettRichard BurgonWhich may come as news to them. pic CmTAeImdash Tom HarwoodDecember , Amelia Womack, deputy leader of the Green Party, says climate change is a #priority for people across the country# despite the fact it wasnt mentioned in tonights debate.She says: #I find it frustrating, as a younger woman, that we werent discussing things that are relevant to my generation # whether thats house prices, rental prices, freedom of movement across Europe, or even zero-hour contracts.#Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: corbyn rmt strike railways crhsitmas 1970s
story: The partys pitch is certainly well-timed, as fresh rail strikes bring commuters to their knees - yet the Labour Party is no friend of the commuter, pocketing £million from strike-loving UNITE and promising to rip down the nations defences against industrial action.Just yesterday, shadow chancellor John McDonnell was even caught on video promising the militant RMT union it would be in government with us and advisers on policy.The unions used to be the authentic voice of working people - now they are the shrill cry of subsidised privilege.Train drivers are among the top earners in Britain, some of them enjoying pay packages over £, for a four-day-week.This week sees the start of the longest rail strike in British history, as RMT members walk out at the South Western railway in a row over the role of guards on a new generation of trains.The action, due to last no fewer than  days, has already brought chaos for the  million passengers who use this vital part of the network.Covering much of southern England, South Western operates services between Waterloo – the UK’s busiest station, with , daily users – and Bournemouth, Southampton, Exeter, Bristol, Reading, and Portsmouth, as well as swathes of the Home Counties commuter belt.At least  trains a day - around half of all services - will have to be cancelled because of the strike.In the run-up to Christmas, the disruption is certain to be horrendous. Work schedules will be wrecked, family gatherings halted, parties ruined.Anyone who relies on the train for their employment – including emergency staff – will find le impossible. Some will face genuine hardship because of the loss of earnings.RMT members say theyre striking for passenger safety, but this is just a smokescreenThose who try to use the skeleton service face massive overcrowding, congested s and packed carriages.One woman even fainted yesterday on the . line from Woking to Waterloo yesterday morning because of over-crowding.The current strike is part of a long-running dispute on the railways over union objections to the introduction of driver-only operated trains.Since , there have been regular walkouts, such as the three days of strike action on South Western in January last year, which saw the cancellation of  trains.This time, the RMT claims that it is acting “in defence of passenger safety” over changes in the guards’ job descriptions and the removal of their responsibilities of operating the train doors.But this is just a smokescreen. The genuine, more sinister, motivations for the strike are twofold: first to defend their members’ present conditions, no matter how outdated, inefficient or inappropriate second, to promote Labour’s agenda of nationalisation by discrediting the private operators.It is no coincidence that the RMT’s biggest ever strike began during the final full week of campaigning in the General Election.No sector in the British economy would welcome a Jeremy Corbyn government more the trade unions, which are desperate to win back the influence they held in the s.In turn, Labour is seeking to win over disillusioned rail passengers by promising massive cuts in ticket prices.Just as the RMT strike began today, Corbyn’s party announced that it would reduce regulated fares by  per cent, a move cynically targeted at commuters.The unions barons have a stranglehold on Labour, not least because they effectively bankroll the party. It is no exaggeration to say that Labour is the political wing of the union movement.Out of the total donations of £ million to Labour in , the unions gave £. million.The biggest sum, £ million, came from UNITE, led by Corbyn ally “Red Len” McCluskey, the hard-left Merseysider who once boasted that he had led more strikes than any other union boss in Britain.Last week, it was revealed that UNITE has just handed over a further £ million to Labour’s General Election fund.A further £, came from the Communication Workers Union, which has been threatening disruption in the Royal Mail in the run-up to Christmas.That spirit of confrontation would dramatically worsen under Corbyn.If he became PM, he would make it much easier for the unions to hold strikes.His Government would repeal most of the vital reforms introduced by Margaret Thatcher, such as restraints on picketing, democratic rules on ballots and bans on sympathy walkouts.Corbyn’s manesto states that his party plans “to remove unnecessary restrictions on industrial action”, as part of a drive “to create new rights and freedoms for trade unions.”That is a recipe for permanent industrial crisis and economic meltdown.A Corbyn-led Government will turn the clock back to the s, when the bullying union barons brought the country to a standstill.Last year, just , working days were lost to strike action. In , the total was  million and in , during the Winter of Discontent, a colossal . million working days were lost.For most of the British people, that period was a nightmare. But for Corbyn, McDonnell and their allies in the trade unions, it was a time of glorious advance.Their party and supporters are the very last people who would stand up to the trade unions. On the contrary, they will be cheering on the militants, justying all their industrial vandalism and bullying.And, as the climate of appeasement spreads, the dominance of the unions will tighten.The RMT will be at the forefront of the chaos, not least because its General Secretary Mick Cash – who is on a fat cat package of £,-a-year – shares Corbyn’s hard left outlook.Cash recently praised the Labour leader for “the socialist advances that have been made in the party.”This month’s RMT strike gives a disturbing glimpse into dark future that awaits Britain under Corbyn.Behind all its empty rhetoric about concern for the public, the union’s justication for imposing gridlock is as baseless as it is cruel.Contrary to the RMT’s scare-mongering, driver-only operated trains are safer and have a lower record of assaults. That reality was reinforced by a study in  by the Independent Rail Safety and Standards Board, which gave them a clean bill of health.Moreover, the union cannot pretend that rail staff are badly treated.Most of them enjoy far better conditions, holidays, job security, and pensions than their counterparts outside the public services. Like Corbyn’s Labour, the RMT has lost the plot. For the sake of our country, Mick Cash and his fellow unions barons should not be allowed any more power.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nish kumar left wing comedians bbc
story: He meant I was a state-school lad and I suppose his implication was that independent schools were somehow more free-thinking and more reliable bastions of excellence.At the time, I could only see the other side of that particular argument.But the phrase has come to mind again in a dferent context.The disastrous reception given to comedian Nish Kumar at the Lord’s Taverners festive lunch on Tuesday is a sign the maintained sector of British comedy has fallen victim to lazy groupthink and general mediocrity.Kumar, who was booed offstage by his mainly provincial, “small c” conservative audience — albeit at a swanky London venue — made the mistake of rolling out the usual anti-Brexit, anti-Tory observations lapped up by the live audiences of his BBC show The Mash Report.He got a bread roll thrown at his head for his trouble.I am sure Kumar is not entirely without talent. Clearly it takes courage to stand before an audience charged with being funny enough to quieten the clink of cutlery.But let’s be frank. He is simply another BBC comedian with acceptable views.BBC-approved comedians dominate the maintained sector of British comedy.Auntie is the superpower of sponsored satire, scattering municence in the direction of any up-and-coming talent with a neat line in attacking approved targets: The patriarchy, Brexit, Nigel Farage, Boris Johnson, Tories, country-sports enthusiasts, royalists and Priti Patel. You get the picture.Of course, not all comedians rely on such sketches. But those that don’t often pay the price.Take talented young comedian Alistair Williams, who shot to prominence off the back of a sketch in which he likened Brexit to being stuck in a Burger King you have voted to leave. His video soon went viral.But as he noted on Twitter the next day: “Because I am a comedian that supports Brexit, you can no longer find me on the comedy club circuit.”There are exceptions. Pro-Brexit comedian Geoff Norcott is gradually finding his way on to a few BBC shows.Simon Evans is a successful comic who parodies his own upper-middle class, right-of-centre viewpoint, while occasionally getting in an anti-leftist dig along the way.But compare that to the roll call of liberal-left comics who pop up on the BBC: Ed Byrne, Dara O Briain, Marcus Brigstocke, Jolyon Rubinstein, Sandi Toksvig, Mitchell and Webb, Mark Steel, Mark Thomas, Jo Brand, Andy Parsons, Russell Howard and Stewart Lee.These and others form a rolling castlist for the BBC’s many radio and TV  and sketch shows, trotting out the same takes to approving titters from audiences apparently bussed in en-masse from North London.A few weeks ago, after enduring a standard Have I Got News For You anti-Brexit fest, I turned over to watch Mock The Week on BBC to see host Dara O Briain tell a list of Malaysian heritage he wouldn’t be welcome in the Brexit Party .I vented about it on Twitter because whatever you think of the Brexit Party, it has been notably erse since its inception. O Briain’s lazy smear made no sense.It quickly transpired the one Malaysian-born person to achieve senior elected office in the UK is Christina Jordan, who is the Brexit Party’s MEP for Gibraltar and the South West.Soon she was giving O Briain an ear-bashing.His retort was that he got a laugh from the studio audience because that was what they thought of the Brexit Party.No wonder, eh Even some of those on the BBC’s roster have clocked that their unormity of outlook might be a problem.Brigstocke spoke in  of the shock of seeing audience members walk out of his show during his anti-Brexit segment when he took it on tour round the country.But comedy as a whole shows few signs of coming to terms with the case for more erse thinking.Most of us not on the Left do not close our minds to the possibility of those we disagree with still being funny.The late Jeremy Hardy’s Tory takedowns on Radio ’s The News Quiz were brilliant.But most comics don’t work hard enough to offer such original material.Jo Brand’s joke about battery acid being thrown over politicians is a case in point.We get she probably doesn’t really wish that on anyone. It is another way for her to say she doesn’t like particular politicians.We knew that.Thankfully, salvation is at hand.An independent sector is sprouting up, taking advantage of social media and hosting free-thinking comedy nights.Lee Hurst, a veteran whose broadcast career was curtailed for not being reliably left-wing, is a patron of the scene.In performers such as Williams, Norcott, Evans and Titania McGrath satirist Andrew Doyle — plus free-wheeling left-wingers such as Francesca Martinez and American Rob Delaney — we see the makings of a new alternative-comedy scene.Seek them out, ditch the BBC and have a laugh.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: french air strikes december 2019 air traffic controll pensions
story: Workers from all professions - including air traffic controllers - will strike. But when do they start, who is striking and how will it affect the UK  Heres everything you need to know.The national strikes began at pm on December .Strikes are expected to continue over the coming weekend, until December .Some industries strikes, like Eurostar for instance, will protest for longer - Eurostar plans to strike from December  to .However, some trade union bosses have warned they will continue with industrial action until Macron backtracks on his unpopular pension plan.Its thought to be the largest nationwide strike in Frances history.The strikes were agreed by unions unhappy with the Presidents plans for a universal points-based pension system.The basic idea is that employees would earn points for each day worked, which would later turn into pension benefits upon retirement.Currently, Frances pension system is not unied and it means certain professions - like lawyers and opera workers - retire with cushy pensions.Macrons new system aims to recty this but it also means that those retiring before the age of  would lose out.Someone retiring in France at age  under the new scheme would receive five per cent less than someone retiring one year later.Frances current system is one of the most expensive in the world, and taking into account people living much longer these days, costs are only set to increase.But workers on both ends of the scale argue that a singular scheme fails to accommodate for iniduals working lives. workers, for instance, have a long-negotiated early retirement as compensation for the gruelling work, long hours and endless shts spent underground.Thousands of workers from all sectors are thought to be striking.Those taking industrial action are:Frances interior minister predicted on the evening the strike commenced some  demonstrations - but official numbers are yet to be released.He said: We know there will be lots of people in these protests and we know the risks. I have requested that systematically when there is rioting or violence we make arrests immediately.The strikes could affect thousands of Brits as EasyJet, British Airways, Ryanair and Eurostar cancel numerous services.When the French Air Traffic Controllers went on strike earlier in , over  flights had to be cancelled.The Foreign and Commonwealth Office warned of severe delays that could affect trains, metros, busses and trams across France.Brits heading to France should therefore check before they travel to make sure services are still running.Brits heading to France next week should therefore check before they travel to make sure services are still running.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy corbyns loony left lethal left
story: But like millions of other Remain voters, I am a democrat first and foremost. I have accepted the result and I support Boris’s deal. The country must move on.It is fundamental to democracy that we implement the will of the people. Yet too many MPs have forgotten they promised to abide by the people’s decision.They spent three years trying to frustrate the result. Now they want to waste the next five doing the same.Every time one of the ultra-Remainers’ spurious claims is defeated, they invent another.They said Boris could not reopen the Withdrawal Agreement and Brussels would not budge. Boris stood his ground and proved them wrong.Now they say we will face a new clf-edge No Deal at the end of next year unless a trade deal is completed with the EU.But there is no comparison with what faced us before. We will have left the EU by then.Two big concerns — citizens’ rights and Northern Ireland — will have been dealt with.It is true that time will be tight. For that we can blame the MPs who did everything in their power to delay our exit.But Boris has proved he is an effective negotiator. Both sides want a trade deal and our economies are already aligned, making agreement easier.With a working majority, Boris’s hand will be stronger and the job will be done. Ultra-Remainers have conjured up this new No Deal spectre because they are desperate.They know thatBoris wins the General Election, we will leave the EU by the end of January and the game will be up.Their second referendum campaign is in tatters and the Liberal Democrats’ pledge to revoke Brexit has bombed.The clock is counting down to an election that could settle the issue once and for all. So they are resorting to ever-more ludicrous claims.So-called moderates should be ashamed of the insults they are hurling at Boris.It is absurd to call his agenda “far-right” or “extreme”.This language should be reserved to describe hateful movements such as the BNP or the National Front.It should not be casually thrown around by fools who have been so blinded by their hatred of Brexit they have lost all sense of proportion.Boris was a successful Mayor of London who won a second term and delivered for the public.His plans to boost funding for schools and the NHS, for more police and to increase the National Living Wage, are clearly mainstream.When Boris calls for tougher sentences for violent criminals, he is speaking squarely for the millions of quiet Brits who share these views.They hate being branded as extremists by metropolitan elitists who have lost touch with everyday concerns.Liberal Conservatives like me are entirely comfortable supporting today’s party.I have marched alongside Boris for gay rights. I have heard him speak passionately about protecting the environment. I have walked down streets and seen him connect with people like no other politician can.I cannot understand how anyone who previously called themselves a Conservative could bring themselves to urge people to vote against the party at this election.That is tantamount to saying Jeremy Corbyn should be PM.These Tory turncoats justy themselves by claiming Brexit will damage the economy. But the public rejected that argument when they voted for Brexit.And you can’t warn about jobs and investment while being willing to allow the catastrophic impact of a government led by Corbyn and Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell.Never in my letime have I seen an agenda like Labour’s today: Ruinous nationalisation spending pledges the country cannot begin to pay for theof crushing union power a leader who has consistently sided with our country’s enemies and who refuses to tackle endemic racism in his own party.This isn’t the loony left. It is the lethal left.It is a blood-red recipe to crash the economy, impoverish our public services and relegate Britain to a third-rate power.No moderate should even consider supporting it. One by one, former Labour MPs are calling out Corbyn, warning us of the dangers.Why can’t the ultra-Remainer former Tory MPs and muddled old warhorses like Lord Heseltine, who once understood the threat of socialism, see it Blinded by their hatred of Brexit, they say the election offers a Hobson’s choice between two extremes.That is hogwash. There is no equivalence between Corbyn’s hard-left programme and Boris’ mainstream Conservative agenda.Evenyou want the referendum result reversed, which most people do not, a neo-Marxist in No cannot be a price worth paying.It is time for those who call themselves moderates to wake up and realise the truly extreme step would be to help make Corbyn PM next week.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: angela merkel auschwitz germany concentration camp visit
story: It comes amid growing fears for the German Chancellors health after she was seen shaking uncontrollably in public at least three times.However the growing health concerns did not interfere with todays ceremony, as Merkel paid tribute to the .million who died in Auschwitz more than  years ago.The vast majority of whom the Nazi regime murdered at Auschwitz-Birkenau were Jewish.Merkel is taking part in a ceremony alongside a camp survivor and Polish Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki during her visit.It comes amid a rise in German anti-Semitism and ahead of the th anniversary of the camps liberation.In October, a gunman in Halle killed two people while attempting to storm a synagogue on Yom Kippur, the holiest day in the Jewish calendar.A German government spokesperson said Merkel travelled to Auschwitz to commemorate the victims of the National Socialist crimes and remember Germanys everlasting responsibility for the Shoah.The camp was liberated on January  by the rapidly advancing Soviet troops – the date is now commemorated each year as Holocaust Memorial Day.Auschwitz, the largest of the Nazi death camps, was the scene of the most appalling mass murder in human history.It was an event that shocked the world when the full extent of the horror came to light.It was a genocide carried out during World War II, where Jews were targeted among other groups.The Romani people, ethnic Poles, Soviet citizens, Soviet prisoners of war, political opponents, homosexuals and Jehovahs Witnesses were also killed.Any group which did not match the behaviour of the prescribed norms was targeted.The Nazis were the orchestrators of the Holocaust.After coming to power in , Adolf Hitlers government passed laws to exclude Jews from society - most notably the Nuremberg Laws in .Following the invasion of Poland in  ghettos were set up to segregate Jews, and more than ,  camps and other detention sites created.Nazi Germany occupied or influenced many countries during the war, and killed nearly two out of every three European Jew as part of the Final Solution.The Allies won the war and liberated the survivors from the remaining death camps in .The Nazi regimes state-sponsored persecution resulted in up to million deaths overall.It was estimated in the United Stated Holocaust Memorial Museum that -million people had died or been imprisoned.Many of those who survived the horrors of the Holocaust found shelter in displaced persons camps.Between  and  almost , Jews migrated to Israel, with others heading to the United States and other nations.The last displaced persons camp closed in .During the Holocaust over a million people – the vast majority of them Jews – lost their lives at the sprawling complex.Major events are planned for the anniversary of the camps liberation, however the German Chancellor decided to visit the site before that date.Merkel was invited to attend the th anniversary of the Auschwitz-Birkenau Foundation, a group that tries to preserve the camp as a memorial and a warning for future generations.There, she held a minutes silence at the Black Wall, where prisoners were executed in the original camp.She also placed a wreath at the Birkenau death camp.Earlier this year, German Jews were warned by a leading government official not to wear traditional kippahs in public settings because of safety concerns following the rise in anti-Semitic attacks.In October, Merkel referenced statistics by the European Fundamental Rights Agency, which said  per cent of the Jews interviewed in Germany think anti-Semitism is growing.Her visit to Auschwitz is another important gesture in the fight.The foundation wrote: Help us to warn humanity against itself. Do not allow history to become a deafening silence. Save the memory.Although the German leader has visited other concentration camps, this is her first visit to the Nazi site.The concentration camp was constructed in the suburbs of the Polish city Oświęcim, near the modern nations southern border, in .In total, an estimated . million people were sent to Auschwitz – and at least . million of these died.Around  per cent of the dead were Jewish, representing approximately a sixth of all Jews killed in the Holocaust.The rest of the inmates were comprised of Polish and Soviet prisoners, thousands of Romany people and an unknown number imprisoned for being homosexual.

story: Connelly, , appeared before the parole board last month and gave an “impassioned plea” to be let out in the coming weeks.But it was confirmed that board members ruled she not changed her ways and is still a signicant risk to the public.And she must now spend up to two more years behind bars at HMP Low Newton in Durham.An insider said: “Connelly applied for parole at the earliest opportunity in November and as soon as she got her date she was focused on it.“She believes she was only kept in so long because the public hate her.“But the parole board clearly thought she was deluded, lacked remorse and saw she still couldn’t take responsibility for what she did to her baby boy.“Authorities are conscious of the public’s anger over what she allowed to happen to her innocent little boy, so no risks are being taken as far as she’s concerned.”Tracey Connelly was given an indefinite sentence after she admitted allowing her then-boyfriend Steven Barker and his brother, Jason Owen, to torture and kill her -month-old son Peter in .The tragic tot suffered a broken back, shattered ribs, missing fingernails and mutilated fingers - most of which were missed by social workers and doctors in the months leading up to his death.She was released in  but called back to prison when it was found she had breached the terms of her licence by selling sordid pictures of herself online to sickos turned on by her past.Connelly first applied for parole in December  but her appeal was unanimously rejected.The insider continued: “She’s spent most of her free time in the lead up to the case in her cell as she didn’t want another inmate starting trouble with her and affecting her hearing.“She’s kept her head down and tried to be a model prisoner and tried to show she’s a changed woman.”Insiders confirmed Connelly gave evidence in person to the parole board about the “poor choices” she made in the past and how she has learned from them.She told members that she was planning on “starting a new le and settling down” far away from her old le in North London.She also revealed how she hopes to rebuild a relationship with her three older daughters.Sources said she has been writing to them from her cell but they are understood to have refused to snubbed her overtures.But parole members declined to agree with her, knocking back her appeal and telling her she is not eligible to re-apply for parole again until at least November .A spokesman for the Parole Board said last night: “We can confirm that a  of the Parole Board did not direct the release of Tracey Connelly following an oral hearing in November .Under current legislation Ms Connelly will be eligible for a further review within two years. title: jack reacher book social media
story: If the survey had said that a fth don’t have a dog, or a hydro-electric dam or a spaceship, I’d have been fine. But how can you not have a table How do you eat  Where do you have coffee  What do you put your shopping on when you come home  And where do you sityou want to read something  Which brings me on to another astonishing fact. Today, in Britain, , children do not own a single book.Obviously, I’m aware that children would much rather shoot an alien in the face than read some drivel by Jane Austen. And I get that. I’d rather gouge my own eyes out with a trowel than read anything by Jane Austen. And I’d certainly rather play Call Of Duty.I’ll admit, too, that book people spend far too much time being bookish and earnest with other book people. Which is why the book that wins the Booker Prize is always more impenetrable than a Hawthorn bush.It’s usually just a lot of women wondering about flowers. Have I read either of this year’s joint winners  No. I’d rather eat my own sick. But the idea of living in a house with no books at all is actually quite frightening.Because then there’d be no Winnie The Pooh, and more worryingly, no Jack Reacher.They’ve tried to capture the essence of this man mountain on television and, hilariously, with Tom Cruise in the role at the cinema, but nothing beats the books. They’re all the same. Jack walks into a small town in America. He has some coffee. Notices a pretty girl. Punches eight men in the face. Sleeps with the pretty girl. Saves the town from the baddies by punching them all in the face and then walks off at the end.I swear to God thatyou could get your kids to put down their phones for a day, and read a Jack Reacher book, they’d never want to do social media again. I know that’s impossible. I know you can’t get a kid to put down its phone for more than  seconds. I’m just saying thatyou could . . .So what about school  Kids are made to read by teachers, but the books they select are always as dull as being dead. Andyou make kids read boring books for exams, they will grow up to hate reading.So ditch Austen and Donne and Shakespeare and Milton. Put them on the top shelf of a library and leave them there. Instead, to make reading fun, make them study Jack Reacher and books by Jilly Cooper and Jeffrey Archer.Even EL Jamesthat’s what it takes. Anything that gets them reading. Anything that makes books cool. It won’t work for everyone of course. Some kids will not enjoy a book no matter how good the story might be.But that’s OK. They can go off and do carpentry instead. Then they could make the family a table.APPARENTLY,  people complained about a raunchy appearance by the Pussycat Dolls on last weekend’s X Factor final.Some say the performance was “shameful” while others said the “strip show” was “absolutely disgraceful”.I couldn’t agree more. We sat through a rubbish song and at the end, they were wearing exactly the same amount of clothing as they had been at the start.But almost all of them these days are NEVER seen in public without a phone in one hand and . . . a plastic bottle of water in the other.I don’t know when it became compulsory to have water about your person at all times, but it’s stupid.Yes. You need wateryou are in the desert and you’re hundreds of miles from a tap and it’s C.But at all other times, you should drink beer.Because that comes in a glass bottle that doesn’t end up wrapped round some poor unfortunate sea creature’s head.AFTER about three hours my back bottom went to sleep but the rest of me was still gripped by Martin Scorsese’s new epic, The Irishman.Mostly, however, I was gripped by how badly the phenomenally expensive de-ageing technology works.It’s used in flash- backs to turn ageing stars Robert De Niro and Al Pacino into younger men but it makes them look like Bill and Ben.And their plastic faces are at odds with their elderly bodies.Pity. I was rather hoping we could use tech like this in the next Grand Tour to make me look like Charles Leclerc.It’s reckoned that David has climbed  places in the list of most popular boys’ names thanks to the work done by David Attenborough.Really. But what about those who are naming their kids after David Cameron, or David Jason Or even the popular television channel.That’s what I’d doI had another kid.Call it Amazon. Good name actually.I SEE Q Branch has fitted James Bond’s rebuilt Aston Martin DB with mini guns that pop out from behind the headlights.That’s excellent, as a brace of these fearsome weapons can fire , rounds a minute. That’s  every second.The trouble is, that they can’t. I once flew a helicopter that had been fitted with miniguns on its skids and every time I pulled the trigger, one bullet would set off in the wrong direction and then the gun would jam.There’s another issue too. If Bond’s car carries enough bullets for two minutes of sustained fire, he’d need , bullets. Which together would weigh around ,lb. Oh, and the ammo storage box would be huge, too.These, then, are weapons that only really work on the screen. When they’re not actually firing anything at all.ELDERLY residents in the seaside town of Bournemouth started a petition as soon as they heard that a “pot shop” was due to open in their community.They said: “The area already struggles massively with anti-social behaviour and the last thing the community needs is an establishment promoting the use of narcotics right opposite impressinable youngsters.”Couple of things on that. They spelled “impressionable” wrong. And more importantly, the pot shop that had got them so riled was going to sell . . . pottery.This is a bit like that story from a while ago where angry locals daubed slogans and smashed windows of the house of the local paediatrician.Because they thought the brass plaque on the door said “paedophile”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tory majority or calamity hung parliament
story: We’re told that every election is the most important in a generation. That’s not true this time: it is the MOST IMPORTANT VOTE in our letimes.At stake is whether we leave the EU or not. You may think that was settled by the Brexit referendum — and it should have been. But any result other than a Tory majority will lead to more efforts to overturn the referendum result.It will mean another year when politicians argue about whether to accept what people voted for in June , rather than focusing on schools, hospitals and all the other domestic issues that matter so much.There are TWO POSSIBLE RESULTS in this election: a Tory majority or another hung Parliament. Even John McDonnell, the Shadow Chancellor, is talking about how Labour would try to governit didn’t have a majority.Another hung Parliament would be more of the same: Parliamentary gridlock and no progress. What would a Parliament without a majority for any party be able to agree on beyond a second referendum It is not even certain it could do that. You would need a government for a second referendum and Jo Swinson, the Liberal Democrat leader, has said she would rather have another election than put either Boris Johnson or Jeremy Corbyn into No.So we may well all be heading to the polls AGAIN in Februarythere is no clear result this time. Eventhey could unite on a second referendum, they wouldn’t be able to agree on much . It would be a single-issue government, to the detriment of everything .When Labour make extravagant promises it has a double credibility problem. First, how will it pay for them  It is not realistic to say you can fund spending equivalent to half an NHS every year just by taxing the rich and big business a bit more.Second, will they actually happen given that Labour won’t win a majority  In a hung Parliament, Labour will only be able to do those things that Nicola Sturgeon’s Scottish Nationalists and the Liberal Democrats agree to.By contrast, a Tory majority government would not be more of the same. It would break the Brexit deadlock. This country would leave on January . This will not settle the question of Britain’s future relationship with the EU, but it will mean that Brexit won’t continue to suck up all of Parliament’s energies.A majority government is also more easily held to account. If the Tories win one, then at the next election voters will be able to seethey have delivered on what they said that would do: There will  be no excuses and no hiding places. Right now, the Tories are on course for a majority. I understand their own internal numbers indicate a working majority.But these margins are very fine, and victory could slip awayvoters don’t turn out. If Boris Johnson does win a majority next week, it will be because he has presented himself as change. Not just the person who can break the deadlock, but a leader with a dferent agenda to the one the Tories have had these past nine years.As Prime Minister of a majority government, he would have to deliver on that agenda. He would have to create the conditions for the economy to flourish far outside London and the South East, he would have to improve the NHS and our infrastructure.Having been elected as a dferent kind of Tory, he will have to govern as that. This country has been in limbo for too long. It needs a Parliament that can take decisions, not just play for time.According to one campaign source: “There is still a nervousness about letting it run wild.”But there is a recognition that the Tories  need a bit of pizzazz in the last few days and that Boris  needs, “the energy of a walkabout”.The Tory plan is to “close hard”. They are, privately, cautiously optimistic.One Cabinet minister says: “In  you could feel it slipping away, it doesn’t feel like that this time.”But they have held back nearly all their online advertising budget for the last few days to guard against any last-minute swing back to Labour.FEW expected Donald Trump to be able to resist getting involved in the election on his visit here for the Nato summit.But in the end, Trump, largely, kept his views to himself.I understand that his son-in-law, Jared Kushner, was key in persuading him not to derail Boris Johnson’s election effort.Kushner, who has a leading role at the White House, developed a good relationship with Johnson when the latter was Foreign Secretary and was keen not to have the visit create any distractions.If he doesn’t, we will  have a second referendum where voters will be asked to choose between Remain and Remain-lite. Nigel Farage is badly miscalculating in his refusal to tell voters in Labour Tory marginals to back the Tories.If Labour hold on in seats such as High Peak in Derbys, it will be because of the Brexit Party standing in a seat that it has no chance of winning.One veteran Eurosceptic who has been part of an effort to get the Brexit Party to make clear that voters shouldn’t back it where it has no chance of winning blames Richard Tice, the Brexit Party chair and its candidate in Hartlepool, for blocking any such move.This source tells me Tice is “a nightmare, he is a far bigger problem than Farage”.This election is going to come down to fine margins. The Brexit Party vote could well let Labour hang on in some crucial seats.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris time world cup came home
story: But no invention has captured the imagination like the one that has  people chasing after a round ball trying to thrash it into a nylon net.The emotions football generates to so many are like nothing  — and no event generates them more than the World Cup.In the past half-century, it’s yielded many magic moments.Marco Tardelli wheeling away like his eyes were going to explode out of his head after scoring Italy’s second in the - win over the then West Germany in the  final.Gazza wiping away his tears with his England shirt in . South Korean jubilation at knocking out the mighty Germans last year.Yet none happened here where the sport began. In fact, not since  — when Bobby Moore held aloft the Jules Rimet trophy — has our great nation hosted the World Cup.It’s time for football to come home. That’s why,elected, I’ll put our Government machine at the heart of a UK and Ireland  World Cup bid.This is about more than staging the tournament. I want it to transform le chances. SoI’m elected next week, I’ll invest £million in order that, within ten years, everyone in England will be, on average, within  minutes of a great local pitch.Above all, I want it to unite us in celebration like the  Olympics did when I was London’s Mayor.I want it to show our national confidence as we get Brexit done: a sign to the world that whilst we are a small country, we’re a great one with a proud history and a strong future.Because, let’s be honest, for the past three and a half years politicians have squabbled over Brexit rather than delivering it — going round in circles rather than focusing on our schools, hospitals and keeping our streets safe.That’s why I had to call the election and why I’m asking Sun readers to visit their local polling station next week.  As you do, cast your mind back five weeks to the endless shouting in parliament. And then imagine five more years of it.In le, as in football, there are moments. Moments when you have to choose. Moments when things come together — or when they fall apart.Moments that define history and set the course of the future.We all remember Gareth Southgate’s heartfelt celebrations last summer and that Eric Dier penalty.We slightly overlook how close the keeper was to saving it. Thankfully he didn’t and we put years of penalty heartbreak behind us.In politics, one of those moments is coming next Thursday.We can either deliver Brexit and move forward with a Conservative majority Government, or we can have more Brexit delay, more arguing in Parliament, and two more referendums in  under Jeremy Corbyn. Next Thursday, I’m asking many dferent people to come on a journey with me. People who always vote Conservative. People who used to but lost faith. People who never have before.All of you who do are putting your trust in me. And I don’t take that lightly at all. Yet I feel so positive about our future as a country outside the EU. There’s so much we can achieve as well as lots we need to improve too.It won’t always be easy. We won’t always agree. But together I really believe we can do it. So come with me on that journey. Let’s unleash our potential. Let’s get Brexit done. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Researchers say their findings debunk the myth that a caesarean birth raises the odds of a child growing fat.Instead, the mum’s body mass indexbefore she falls pregnant is the biggest predictor of her kid’s adult size.Scientists analysed the birth method and BMI of , men aged  using records from military service conscription exams.Some . per cent of those delivered naturally were obese, compared with . per cent born through elective c-section and . per cent by emergency c-section.But there was no statistical dference after accounting for other factors such as the age, smoking status and BMI of the mum.Dr Daniel Berglind who led the Swedish study said: “This tells us that how women give birth may not be an important factor in the origins of the global obesity epidemic.”One in four UK babies is delivered by c-section. title: banana artwork duct taped sells

title: jeremy corbyn martmite candidate
story: The Labour boss conceded he is not to everybody’s taste when he was quizzed on why so many working class voters are deserting the party.Bizarrely relishing in being isive, he told a London press conference: “I think Marmite’s really good for you.“Some people like it and some people don’t. It says there will be customs declarations, absolutely clearly, for trade going from Northern Ireland to Great Britain.”But Tory sources furiously downplayed the document, insisting it was a “flash” and incomplete analysis of the deal.And Boris hit back while on the campaign trail in Kent, branding the document’s claims “complete nonsense”.The PM said: “There will be no checks from goods going from Great Britain to Northern Ireland because we are going to come out of the EU whole and entire and that was the objective we secured.“And it’s a vast improvement on the original proposal which would indeed have carved out Northern Ireland and kept it in the EU for all sorts of purposes, we were able to do a fantastic deal for our country.”Mr Corbyn also revealed Labour would give  and -year-olds the vote before they hold a second referendum - a move critics warn will skew the result to stop Brexit.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says boris only sane choice
story: Ignore the choreographed abuse being hurled at the PM by Remainer politicians and their media friends.The Tory leader is the only sane choice next Thursday and millions of BBC viewers saw why during last night’s live debate.Corbyn’s Brexit plan is ludicrous: Negotiating a new deal no one in his party would champion, then campaigning against it in a referendum he would rig against Leavers by giving votes to children and EU migrants.That is patently not what Britain wants.The PM, with a majority, can simply get us out of the EU on January .On the NHS, Corbyn trotted out his baseless conspiracy theory about the Tories selling it to Trump. It was clear how preposterous the audience found it.He then claimed, absurdly, that socialism has a better record than capitalism for raising the poor’s living standards.That will be news to Venezuela, which Corbyn once hailed as an ideal ­economic model but which is now a ­living hell of starvation and squalor.Boris was simply more convincing and more statesmanlike. Corbyn, even in a suit, is still the same old backbench crank nursing -year-old grievances.It is incredible anyone would consider putting him in power.THE smearing of Boris as a racist by a Channel  “mistake” is an outrage.We pray it was not deliberate. The channel’s journalists make no secret of their loathing for the Tories.Its news chief branded Boris a liar and presenter Jon Snow likes to chant “f*** the Tories”.Assuming it was a genuine error, what does it say about the culture of a ­supposedly impartial TV network that no one questioned it How did this happen  TV chiefs must come clean.The channel’s apology came too late to stop Corbyn’s Twitter trolls spreading it.Six days from the most crucial election in a letime, it’s a sacking offence.IT is time for the men in white coats to wheel off John Major, Tony Blair and their europhile has-been mates to a safe space where they can gibber together out of harm’s way.Brexit derangement has so utterly confused and consumed them that they are now campaigning against a Tory victory — and thus for the only alternative: a Marxist-run Corbyn coalition.They somehow prefer the immediate economic harm and global shock of that to a stable Tory Government delivering on the majority’s democratic will.These old men simply cannot cope with their defeat three years ago and seek vengeance on those who beat them.They really are that barking.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy corbyn labour brexit prime minister
story: But with Boris Johnson elected as the new Tory leader, is this his time to make a leadership move  Heres what we know about Corbyn.Jeremy Corbyn is the leader of the Labour Party.He spent three decades as a backbencher before taking the top spot in the lefty party.Born in Chippenham, Wilts., on May , , Jeremy Corbyn is the youngest of three sons.After attending a private prep school and state grammar school, the politician briefly worked at a local newspaper and at the age of , he volunteered in Jamaica for two years.He then worked as a trade union organiser and was elected a councillor in Haringey, North London, aged .In  Corbyn, , was elected as Labour MP for Islington North - the constituency he has represented ever since.On his website, Corbyn says: “I remain every bit as determined to fight for a better society today, as I was then.As a backbench MP he was known as a radical who backed hard-left policies and voted against his own party more than  times.Following Labour’s defeat in the General Election in May , Corbyn announced he was standing as a candidate as party leader.He was seen as a rank outsider, but stunned Westminster by winning the party leadership in September.According to Spears, the Labour leader’s net worth is a staggering £million.Corbyn has been married three times.His third we, Laura Alez, is an ex-banker who is  years younger than him.Corbyn orced from his second we, Chilean exile Claudia Bracchitta, in  after  years of marriage. They have three sons together.He was married to his first we, academic Jane Chapman, from  to .Corbyn spent most of his -year career as an MP as an obscure backbencher.But in a remarkable turn of events the bearded throwback leftie was propelled from the political fringe to leading the UKs main opposition party.Ed Miliband, who lost the General Election against the odds in , decided to open up future leadership contests to the public for a £ fee.But instead of drawing in a wide spectrum of society, the opportunity to vote was seized by a hard left faction which later became known as Momentum.And so with their support the crumpled maverick won the votes.Corbyn’s low-fi style in contrast to other polished politicians also won him support from young people looking for a no-frills socialist leader.His leadership was then challenged in  after his lacklustre support for the Remain camp in the Brexit vote.After a no-confidence vote was supported by  Labour MPs to  against, a leadership battle began between Corbyn and Welsh MP Owen Smith.But after Momentum marshalled support for him, Corbyn actually increased his leadership from . per cent to . per cent.However, after just four years doing the job it was rumoured he was tired and fed up.Allies have reportedly claimed hell soon hand over to another MP.One Shadow Cabinet member told the Evening Standard: Corbyn is ready to step down. He wants to step down.Corbyn has said that Labour WILL back a second referendum in his latest Brexit flip-flop.The leftie leader said there should be a public vote on any deal agreed by Parliament.His U-turn comes after Labour slipped to third place in the polls with Remainers abandoning the party in favour of pro-EU rivals.The party has previously said it would support a second referendum in order to stop No Deal or a bad Tory deal.But now Mr Corbyn has suggested hell back a so-called peoples vote on any deal at all.The Labour leader told the BBCs Andrew Marr Show: I want us to get a good deal and then have a decision of the public after that.If we can get that through Parliament, the proposals weve put, then I think it would be reasonable to have a public vote to decide on that in the future.Corbyn is campaigning to become the next Prime Minister in the run up to the December  General Election.He will go head-to-head with other party leaders, including current PM Boris Johnson in a number of debates leading  up to the election.A YouGov poll taken on November  revealed the Tories have a  per cent chance of securing the election win.Labour come second with  per cent, and the Lib Dems have  per cent. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: viewers claim corbyn weak national security debate
story: Mr Corbyn and Boris Johnson tussled over security in the wake of last weeks terror attack in London Bridge carried out by convicted terrorist Usman Khan.The PM tried to portray Mr Corbyn as a longtime anti-war and anti-nuclear campaigner, who was soft on security.Many viewers tuning in agreed and accused the Labour leader of appearing weak on the subject.One commentator tweeted: Who would trust Jeremy Corbyn with our national security and the safety and protection of the citizens of this country  To even consider it is horrying.Kevin Alcock, , said: Corbyn did a bit better in the NHS but looks very weak on the security issue.Andrew Robinson wrote: Corbyn is a massive threat to the security of our country.Another viewer tweeted: Corbyn was doing well until the security question.Elsewhere in the debate Mr Johnson pointed out Diane Abbott had previously signed an early day motion to abolish Mi.He said: When you look at Mi, the body that keeps us safe from terror attacks, hes proposing to put in a home secretary in the form of Diane Abbott who has called for Mi to be disbanded.Mr Corbyn was forced to deny that and insisted his party could be trusted on security, pointing out how the Tories had cut police numbers and prison services.Following the terror attack in London Bridge last week, an audience member asked the leaders whether they were prepared to put public safety ahead of human rights.In response Mr Corbyn said: Its not an either or. You have to keep the public safe...you have to give people that security, you dont get security on the cheap.He added: There is no dference between wanting security and human rights, the two things are inextricably linked.Mr Johnson said it was extraordinary and wrong the attacker was given automatic early release after an earlier terrorism conviction.He said: I think it is wrong that someone like Usman Khan...should have been out automatically after eight years when the judge made it clear he was...a risk to public safety.Boris said a Tory government would make sure terrorist served their full sentence - which was met with applause in the audience.Mr Johnson also attacked the Labour leader over his previous support for the IRA.He said: I do find it slightly curious to say the least to be lectured about the union between Great Britain and Northern Ireland by a man who all his political le has campaigned to break up that union and actually supported for four decades the IRA their in their campaign violently to destroy it.However the Tory boss was mocked by viewers for continually trotting out the same lines, including Get Brexit Done and describing his Brexit deal as oven ready.They accused Mr Johnson of repeating the same dull slogans about Brexit.Viewers also accused Mr Johnson of appearing untrustworthy and of waffling his way through the debate with the same soundbites.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc channel 4 bias election
story: The broadcasters have been accused of letting a “sense of entitlement” drive “hysterical” rows with politicians over the race blunder and Andrew Neils on-air challenge to Mr Johnson for an interview.Senior media figures warned that broadcasters risked breaching their obligation to remain impartial during the election by attempting to embarrass leaders into granting interviews.It comes after Neil challenged Mr Johnson for a second time and empty chaired him live on TV.The BBC rottweiler fired the challenge at the PM during his interview with Brexit Party leader Nigel Farage.In a clip viewed six million times on social media, the BBC presenter used an empty chair to emphasise the fact that the PM was refusing to appear.He told The Times: “I don’t think Andrew Neil helped himself by putting out such a public challenge because he made it inevitable that it would be turned down.Lord Grade of Yarmouth, the former BBC and ITV chairman, said that broadcasters were sounding hysterical and urged Ofcom to review rules around empty chairing.He said that Neil’s monologue on Thursday was “pretty close to the edge”.Mr Johnson tonight blasted Jeremy Corbyn for a failure of leadership over Brexit in their final live BBC debate - with just a week to go until polling day.The PM went up against the leftie leader for their last showdown before polling day, and repeatedly attacked him for staying neutral on the biggest issue of the day.But their clash was overshadowed by the row over coverage, which was the latest in a series of disputes between broadcasters, politicians and activists that have resulted in record numbers of complaints of bias.The Beeb was bombarded with a record , complaints in the past fortnight, many about political bias.It comes after Channel  was forced to offer a grovelling apology for fake smears that Mr Johnson made a racist comment on camera.Broadcasting bosses claimed the PM said “people of colour” had to be controlled when coming into Britain – but in fact he had said “people of talent”.Boris said: “Im in favour of having people of talent come to this country but I think we should have it democratically controlled.But a clip of Mr Johnson making the comments at a rally in Kent – with  subtitles - was posted on the channel’s Twitter account and quickly attracted furious tweets bashing the Tory boss.However, Channel  chiefs made a snivelling apology.A spokesman said: “Boris Johnson says “people of talent” not “people of colour.”Our earlier tweet was a mistake. title: harvey weinstein frail ankle bracelet
story: The disgraced movie mogul slowly hobbled into court in Manhattan this afternoon amid his sex assault case in which prosecutors claim he violated bail conditions by mishandling his electronic ankle monitor.The -year-old looked pale and fragile as he was helped arm-in-arm by two aides outside the courthouse in New York.One of the helpers also carried a walking stick for him after he was dropped off outside in a plush motor.He was previously pictured just a few months ago at the same court appearing to look much healthier.The accused sex attacker and Hollywood heavyweight will go on trial in January to face five allegations of sexual assault - Ronan Farrow and Jodi and Megan do that for her.Weinstein is accused of first degree rape, third degree rape, criminal sexual act and two counts of predatory sexual assault.The charges relate to two incidents involving two women one who says she was raped by him in March  and one who says he forced her into performing a sex act on him in .He denies all the allegations against him.We told earlier this week how a former private eye revealed how she befriended Harvey Weinsteins alleged rape victim Rose McGowan after the disgraced movie mogul hired her to spy on his accusers.Israeli Stella Penn Pechanac, , used several aliases to dig dirt on the Scream star and other women with sex assault allegations against Weinstein.The operative at Israeli intelligence firm Black Cube bluffed her way into meetings with McGowan just months before the allegations wrecked the Hollywood producers career.She convinced McGowan she was Diana Filip, an executive from asset management firm Reuben Capital Partners, who wanted the actress to speak at a gala dinner, reports the Mail on Sunday.The pair met for drinks and girls nights out and McGowan even told the spy there was no one  in the world I can trust.Weinstein — who is accused of sexual misconduct against some  women - title: elon musk not liable defamation paedo
story: Vernon Unsworth sued the tycoon over his comment following his part in the rescue of  boys in Thailand.The case stemmed from the pairs very public squabble last year when Mr Unsworth was part of an international team working to save a youth football team and their coach from a flooded cave network.The tech boss said he was building a mini-submarine to guide the boys to safety - but the rescuer told CNN the scheme had absolutely no chance of working and said Musk and his team had been asked to leave.Musk hit back by branding him paedo guy to his millions of followers on Twitter.The caving expert, from St Albans, Herts, fought back tears at court this week as he said being branded a paedophile was a le sentence without parole.His voice cracking with emotion, he said: It feels very raw. I feel humiliated, shamed, dirtied.But A US District Court jury in Los Angeles on Friday found in favour of the Tesla Inc boss in the defamation lawsuit.The verdict was delivered on the fourth day of the trial a short time after the case was handed to the jury of five women and three men.Following the court victory, Musk told The Mail: My faith in humanity is restored.Unsworth was seeking £million damages against Musk, who during the trial estimated his net worth at £billion.He was challenged by Mr Musks lawyers during the casehe wanted to apologise for his own comments.He replied: “My insult was to the tube and not to Mr Musk personally.“I’m not sure how I need to apologise. It was my opinion at the time and I stand by that opinion.”He added: “I don’t think he was cold-hearted, but I do believe it was a PR stunt.”The Brit, , also revealed Prince William spoke to him about the situation that existed with Mr Musk when he awarded him an MBE at Buckingham Palace.The judge stopped him revealing more about the conversation after an objection from Musks attorney.Earlier he had said his upset over the paedo guy tweet meant he could not enjoy what should have been one of the proudest moments of his le.The court also heard from Mr Unsworths estranged we Vanessa, who said he was really devastated by Musks slur and any suggestion he was a paedophile was totally .She said she is incredibly proud of his role in the rescue, despite their split in  when he was already in a relationship with his Thai girlfriend Tik.Musk deleted the pedo guy tweet after a backlash from the public and pressure from investors as his companys stock dipped.But he later labelled the cave er a child rapist in a rambling email to a reporter which he claims he thought was off the record.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. The Prime Minister accused Mr Corbyn of a failure of leadership in his handling of anti-Semitism in the Labour Party.The Labour leader shot back that he never used racist language and that he hoped Mr Johnson regretted his past comments. Viewers of the BBC TV debate believe the Prime Minister narrowly won although it was within the polling margin of error so is effectively too close to call. Those who answered donapost know have been removed from results.Chris Curtis, YouGovaposs political research manager, said: Our snap poll shows that the public remains ided on who won the debate, just as with last monthaposs head-to-head, with most Labour voters thinking Jeremy Corbyn won, most Conservative voters thinking Boris Johnson won, and very few people changing their minds.But given the Conservatives went into this debate in the lead, they will hope the lack of a knockout blow means they can maintain this until voting day. Boris Johnson had a toe-curling response when asked what the punishment should be for politicians who lie. The Prime Minister has been accused of misleading the country on a number of issues including his promises to create , nurse places - , of whom are already working in the service, his promise for  hospitals which transpired as only six and the infamous message on the side of the Vote Leave bus.  At the BBCaposs leadersapos debate in Maidstone, Kent, a member of the audience asked the two leaders what punishment they think is appropriate for elected politicians who lie during political campaigns  The audience laughed at Mr Johnson as he smirked and said politicians who lie during election campaigns should be made to go on their knees down on their knees through the chamber of the House of Commons scourging themselves with copies of their offending documents which claim to prove one thing and actually prove something quite dferent.  One audience member shouted out: Go on then.  Jeremy Corbyn hit back at Boris Johnsonaposs claims that the NHS is not on the table in future trade deals with the US.  During the leadership debate the Labour leader was challenged on his assertion thatthere was a deal with America then Brits would face five-figure bills for cancer treatment.  Mr Corbyn asked the Prime Minister why negotiations had taken two yearsMr Johnson was telling the US that the NHS was not for sale. He said: The Prime Minister says heaposs not going to do that kind of trade deal. If thataposs the case, why did the talks go on for two years  It doesnapost take two years to say no to privatisation of the NHS.  The Labour leader clashed with the Prime Minister during the BBCaposs head-to-head debate less than a week before the election. Host Nick Robinson asked: You donapost dispute what heaposs quoted which is that American trade negotiators say they want more access to the NHS.  He replied: Iaposve made it absolutely clear to everybody that under no circumstances will that happen. Mr Robinson asked Mr Corbyn: You sent an email on behalf of the Labour Party saying aposimagine opening a five figure bill for your cancer treatmentapos, do you accept that is totally misleading - thereaposs no possibility of anybody having NHS cancer treatments and having to pay a five figure bill.  Mr Corbyn replied: If you end up with a privatised service, thataposs what you get. Weaposve heard it time and time again from the Labour Party during this election campaign. But when a nurse asked about dealing with the shortage of staff, it was actually Jeremy Corbyn who shed some new light on policy. Under pressure from BBC host Nick Robinson, Mr Corbyn confirmed Labouraposs ambition to reach a -hour week within a decade was not a hard plan to apply to NHS staff. Mr Corbyn said he wants to see the working week come down, but added: There is no plan to bring in a four day week in the NHS. This appears to contradict Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell who said last month: It’s a -hour week implemented over a ten-year period – it will apply to everyone.  Jeremy Corbynaposs damning attack on the failings of Capitalism  Jeremy Corbyn found himself on stronger ground when talking about capitalism and its failings. After Boris Johnson accused him and his allies of wanting to overthrow capitalism he replied: “My plan is one where you don’t leave people behind. “You don’t ignore the fact that million of our children are living in poverty, you don’t ignore the fact there are thousands of people sleeping on the streets of this country - the fth richest country in the world. The inequality has got worse.  billionaires in Britain, more people poor than ever.” The audience applauded. He added: “We’ve gone too far down the road of free market economics… we’ve created too much inequality.”  Boris Johnson confronted over politicising Jack Merrittaposs death  When the leaders were asked about balancing the needs of security against human rights against in the wake of the London Bridge terror attack, Mr Corbyn said: What happened on the streets of London was utterly appalling and I very moved by what Jack Merrittaposs father said about what his son was trying to do. Mr Johnson had threatened to lock up terrorists and throw away the key - even though victim Jack Merritt’s dad had pleaded for him not to politicise the atrocity.Mr Corbyn slammed the Tory leader: “Yes of course you must imprison them. Yes of course you must try and rehabilitate themyou can.  “But there has to be a monitoring process to achieve that. We need security on our streets. Security doesn’t come on the cheap.   “Andyou cut the number of police officers, cut the number of PCSOs, privatise the probation service, underfund all the other aspects of the criminal justice system, then we all pay a price with our own security.”   Mr Johnson claimed he was putting a huge amount of money into the criminal justice system - even though the Tories have cut expenditure on justice by %, and have announced no plans to increase expenditure except on prisons.
